metadata.title: Understanding bifunctional behavior of Ni/HZSM5 catalyst under isobutane atmosphere

Sola c Narcís Homs c d Pilar Ramírez de la Piscina c Benoit Louis e ⁎ Marcelo Maciel Pereira a ⁎ a Laboratório de Catálise e Energia Sustentável, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil Laboratório de Catálise e Energia Sustentável Instituto de Química Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ) Rio de Janeiro RJ Brazil b Instituto de Química, Departamento de Físico-Química, Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil Instituto de Química Departamento de Físico-Química Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ) Rio de Janeiro RJ Brazil c Departament de Química Inorgànica i Orgànica, Secció Química Inorgànica and Institut de Nanociència i Nanotecnologia (IN2UB), Universitat de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain Departament de Química Inorgànica i Orgànica Secció Química Inorgànica and Institut de Nanociència i Nanotecnologia (IN2UB) Universitat de Barcelona Barcelona Spain d Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC), Barcelona, Spain Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC) Barcelona Spain e Laboratoire de Synthèse Réactivité Organique et Catalyse, Institut de Chimie, UMR7177, CNRS, Université de Strasbourg, France Laboratoire de Synthèse Réactivité Organique et Catalyse Institut de Chimie UMR7177UMR7177 CNRS Université de Strasbourg France ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract I/I0 profiles obtained from DXAS experiments during reduction of Ni/HZSM5 under hydrogen or isobutane. Bifunctional catalysts are widely applied to chemical and petrochemical industry. Herein nickel was introduced by ionic exchange in HZSM5 zeolite resulted in a Ni/HZSM5 catalyst that contains both H+ and Ni2+ as compensation cations of the zeolite framework. This catalyst has been characterized by using different in-situ techniques as Dispersive X-ray Absorption (DXAS), X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS), Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier-Transform (DRIFTS) spectroscopies, Temperature Programmed Reduction experiments (TPR) under both H2 and isobutane atmospheres, and by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) after exposure to H2 or isobutane. The reduction of Ni2+ species under isobutane started at about 120 °C, meanwhile under H2 stream the reduction started at 350 °C. Under isobutane, nickel undergoes a sequential reduction from Ni2+ to Ni+ and then to Ni0 and the number of Brønsted acid sites of the catalyst increased. By increasing the temperature (500 °C), sintering occurs and nickel particles are formed. Keywords Bifunctional catalyst Ni/HZSM5 Alkane cracking In-situ DXAS In-situ DRIFTS Introduction The cracking and the isomerization of hydrocarbons are relevant petrochemical processes in which, the use of H-zeolites as acidic catalysts allows the alkane reaction [1,2]. When H+ in H-zeolites are substituted by metal ions, catalysts with different characteristics can be formed [3] due, among other reasons, to the different possibilities of metal ion localization in the zeolite. The nature of the ion and the method of introduction determine the metallic ion distribution in the zeolite and consequently the evolution of metallic species during the catalytic reaction and the catalytic behavior of the system. This is particularly important when metallic active sites can be formed, then the formation of a bifunctional catalyst with acid and metallic sites can take place [4–7]. The transformation of branched and linear C4 hydrocarbons have been largely studied during last decades due to their participation in different refinery processes [8–13]. The porous structure of H-zeolites and the number, distribution and strength of their acid centers determine the behavior of H-zeolites in the transformation of C4 alkanes [7]. The direct protolytic cracking of C4 alkanes via carbonium ion transition states can be favored using HZSM5 zeolites with pore size restrictions and high Si/Al ratio [12]. In contrast, other zeolites with larger pore size could favor secondary and tertiary reactions such as alkylations and β-scissions involving carbenium ions and bimolecular mechanisms [12]. In a previous work we have reported about the initial step of hydrocarbon activation over acidic zeolites HZSM5 and HUSY [14]. Experiments using isotopic labeled D-USY and isobutane have shown that σ CH and σ CC bonds are directly protonated by D-ZSM5 Brønsted acid sites, leading to HD and CH3D formation as primary products and sequentially [D1]-isobutane. The later product was formed by a bimolecular hydrogen transfer reaction [14]. The presence of Ni in HZSM5 can change the catalytic behavior of the zeolite [15]. Although nickel is active in several catalytic reactions involving hydrocarbons such as dehydrogenation and hydrogenolysis, it is generally accepted that different type of sites are involved in dehydrogenation and CC bond scission and therefore the catalytic behavior of nickel species could change as a function of their characteristics [16,17]. The nickel location and distribution in zeolite cages and channels depends on the nickel introduction method and can also affect the acid properties of the porous host [4,6,15]. The introduction of Ni2+ in the zeolite by pH-controlled precipitation or dry impregnation favors the dispersion of nickel ions on the outer surface of the zeolite with respect their distribution as charge compensation ions [4,15]; Ni2+ cations can form small oligomeric species or even particles according with their hydrolysis properties [18]. By contrast nickel is preferentially distributed as cation-exchanged positions in HZSM5 when the introduction of Ni2+ is carried out by ionic exchange [4,15]. When Ni/HZSM5 was prepared by ionic exchange, it showed much higher activity in isobutane cracking and higher selectivity toward ethylene than both pristine HZSM5 and a Ni/HZSM5 catalyst prepared by impregnation [4]. Such behavior was attributed to the catalyst bifunctionality, metallic and acid sites, that occurred under the reaction conditions in the presence of hydrocarbons [15]. This background led us to study the transformation of a Ni/HZSM5 catalyst containing exchanged Ni2+ in the presence of isobutane. The goal of this work is to provide new insights into the in-situ formation of bifunctional Ni/HZSM5 catalysts with metallic and acid centers during the hydrocarbon activation. For such purposes, a deep characterization of the Ni/HZSM5 catalyst was carried out using different techniques such as reduction at programmed temperature (TPR), powder X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) and high resolution electron transmission microscopy (HRTEM). Moreover, we followed the evolution of the material under the isobutane treatment by in-situ techniques: dispersive X-ray absorption (DXAS), X-ray near edge absorption (XANES) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFTS) spectroscopies. Results are compared and discussed with those obtained when H2 was used as reducing agent. Experimental Catalyst preparation HZSM5 was gently supplied by Petrobras and characterized as described elsewhere [19]. A SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio (SAR) of 25 was determined by X-ray fluorescence using a SPECTRO XEPOS spectrometer equipped with a 50-W end-window X-ray tube to excite the samples. The amount of Brønsted acid sites determined by H/D isotope exchange [20] was 1.58 mmol OH/gcat. The estimated value of Brønsted sites based on the minimum formula of HZSM5, AlnSi96-nO19218H2O is 2.07 mmol OH/gcat. The proximity of these two values suggests that aluminum is mainly located in tetrahedral positions in the HZSM5 framework. Ni2+ was introduced in HZSM5 using the ion exchange method for obtaining a nominal value of 2 wt.% Ni. The pristine HZSM5 was treated with a nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma Aldrich) in aqueous solution (1 mol L−1) at 70–80 °C for 2 h, filtered and washed with distilled water at 65 °C. Finally, the solid was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then treated at 600 °C in a muffle in ambient air for 3 h. Characterization techniques The Ni loading was determined by X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) using a Rigaku RIX-3100 fluorescence spectrometer equipped with an end-window 4 kW Rh X-ray tube (detector scintillation counter, a tube voltage of 50 kV, a tube current of 80 mA, collimater size 450 μm, scanning range of 46–51 °, counting time 0.7 s). The BET surface-area of the samples was determined by means nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C in a Micromeritics equipment (model GEMINI 2375); 99.999% purity N2 was used The BET equation was used in the P/P0 = 0.06-0.21 range. Prior to the analysis, the catalysts were treated under vacuum at 300 °C for 1 h. Brønsted acid sites quantification was performed by monitoring the exchange between deuterated HZSM5 (DZSM5) and water as described elsewhere [20]. The XRD analysis was performed in a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD Alpha1 powder diffractometer equipped with a CuKα1 radiation. The XRD patterns were collected between 2θ = 4° and 2θ = 100°, with a step width of 0.017° and counting 50 s at each step. The mean crystallite sizes were calculated using the Debye-Scherrer equation. HRTEM analysis were carried out with a Phillips 301 microscope working at 300 kV. Samples were previously dispersed in ethanol and coated on a 20-mesh Cu grid, Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out using a Micromeritics AutoChem HP2950 analyzer. The calcined catalyst was pretreated at 90 °C under flowing He. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was exposed to a H2/Ar (12% v/v) or isobutane/Ar (12% v/v) flow (50 mL min−1), and the temperature was linearly increased at 10 °C/min up to 500 °C. DXAS and XANES in-situ measurements were performed in DXAS and XAFS II lines, respectively, at the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS) at Campinas (Brazil), operating at 1.37 GeV with a maximum current of 120 mA. The synchrotron beam was monochromatized by a double-crystal monochromator grooved Si (220). The spectra were collected at the K-edge of nickel (8333 eV) in fluorescence mode using a Ge detector Multi Element. The energy resolution E/ΔE estimated beam was about 5–10 eV in the K-edge of nickel. The catalysts were pressed into pellets and then placed in an induction oven positioned in the synchrotron beam light. For the preparation of each pellet 100 mg of catalyst were used. The spectrum of a nickel foil (6 μm) was measured as reference of Ni0. The catalyst was dried in He from room temperature up to 200 °C and then cooled down to room temperature. Afterwards, a mixture isobutane/He (10% v/v) or H2/He (5% v/v) was introduced in the reactor and temperature was raised at 10 °C/min up to 500 °C with a step at 200 °C hold for 10 min. In-situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out using a Nicolet Magna 750 spectrophotometer, a MCTA liquid nitrogen cooled-detector and a Spectra Tech catalytic chamber with ZnSe windows. Non-diluted catalyst (20 mg) was placed in the catalytic chamber and then treated under He flow at 500 °C before starting the corresponding experiment. The temperature was measured through a thermocouple placed in contact with the catalytic bed. The spectra, registered at different temperatures and under different atmospheres were obtained using the corresponding background of the sample, separately acquired under He at each temperature. The interferograms were acquired with 256 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The purity of He, H2 and Ar used in the experiments was 99.999% and that of CO and isobutane was 99.97% and 99.9%, respectively. Results and discussion Surface area and acid characteristics of Ni/HZSM5 As stated above, Ni/HZSM5 was prepared by ion exchange using HZSM5 previously prepared as described elsewhere [19]. Table 1 shows the BET area, the concentration of Brønsted acid sites and the nickel content of the Ni/HZSM5 and the parent HZSM5. BET values are used here only in terms of comparing our results with previous results reported for Ni/HZSM5 prepared using the same method. The BET surface area of HZSM5 diminished about 15% upon nickel addition, this is in good agreement with previous results reported for Ni/HZSM5 catalysts prepared using the same method [15]. As stated in the experimental section, the number of Brønsted acid sites on HZSM5 and Ni/HZSM5 was determined by H/D isotope exchange technique as reported elsewhere [15,20]. The parent HZSM5 zeolite exhibited 1.58 mmol OH/g; this value fits quite well with the amount of acid sites expected for HZSM5 with a SAR = 25 [15]. The corresponding result determined for Ni/HZSM5 was of 0.64 mmol OH/g. If oligomeric species containing NiONi bonds were formed during the exchange process, the theoretical amount of acid sites for Ni/HZSM5 would be higher than that expected if all Ni2+ species were isolated and exchanged in the zeolite. Meanwhile, the theoretical value expected for Ni/HZSM5 with a 1.96 Ni wt% is 0.92 mmol OH/gcat; it is assumed that all Ni2+ in HZSM5 is exchanged and that every Ni2+ substitutes 2H+ (the Ni/HZSM5 contains 0.33 mmol Ni/gcat, thus 0.66 mmol of Brønsted sites are substituted). The lower amount of Brønsted acid sites found for Ni/HZSM5 than that expected if all Ni2+ ions in the catalyst would be exchanged in the zeolite, could be related with dealumination or debris occurring in the Ni/HZSM5 during the Ni2+ introduction and calcination. However, no representative differences between XRD patterns of Ni/HZSM5 (Fig. 1 a) and that of the parent HZSM5 (JDCPS 01-085-1208) were observed. A similar crystallinity of the catalysts (HZSM5 and Ni/HZSM5) indicates that, after Ni2+ introduction there is no or there is only a limited dealumination. Although the formation of extra framework aluminum species (EFAL) cannot be ruled out, the presence of nickel located as a compensation cation in the zeolite framework may partially hinder the accessibility of D2O molecules toward certain Brønsted acid sites, thus lowering the amount of acid sites measured by the H/D technique compared to the expected value. Acid characteristics and structural changes after isobutane treatment Fig. 2 shows a HRTEM image of Ni/HZSM5 after reaction with isobutane at 500 °C during 2 h; the inset corresponds to the derived Fourier transform pattern of the marked area. The presence of cubic Ni0 particles and rhombohedral graphite is observed; a Ni0 particle size of 10 nm was determined. In a separate experiment we carried out a TPR up to 500 °C under isobutane flow monitoring the amount of water formed by mass spectrometry. Thereafter, the number of Brønsted acid sites of the resulting Ni/HZSM5 sample was measured by D2O exchange. If the isobutane treatment would reduce nickel oligomers, then water would be simultaneously produced. During the isobutane treatment of a sample containing 85 μmol of Ni, 7.8 μmol of water were detected which accounts for approximately one water molecule per ten Ni2+. A non-complete restoring of OH sites after isobutane treatment was found; only 0.4 mmol of OH/gcat were recovered for a sample containing 0.34 mmol Ni2+/gcat. Although this result may be related with a no complete reduction of all the Ni2+ species, other causes could account for it. Particularly the formation of Ni0 particles and/or coke could partially hinder the D2O access to the zeolite acid sites, thus avoiding the determination by H/D exchange of the total amount of OH groups present in this case. The transformation of Ni/HZSM5 during the isobutane treatment was also studied by XANES because the spectra corresponding to the Ni near-edge region of X-ray absorption significantly changes with the Ni oxidation state. Fig. 3 shows the Ni K-edge XANES spectra of Ni/HZSM5 catalyst, before (spectrum a) and after (spectrum b) treatment with isobutane; spectrum c corresponds to a Ni foil introduced as reference. Spectrum a in Fig. 3 was collected in inert atmosphere at 200 °C and shows a main peak at 8346 eV; this peak is attributed to transitions from 1 s to unoccupied final states coming from hybridized 4s, 4p and 3d levels (mainly dipole-allowed 1s → 4p electron transition) [21]. In contrast, the XANES spectrum of Ni/HZSM5 after a treatment under isobutane atmosphere at 500 °C during 30 min (spectrum b in Fig. 3) was similar to the profile of nickel foil (spectrum c in Fig. 3) indicating the presence of Ni0. Also, it is worth mentioning the shoulder at 8335 eV which appeared in both the spectrum of Ni foil and Ni/HZSM5 after the isobutane treatment and did not appear in the initial Ni/HZSM5 spectrum; this feature has been used as indicative of the presence of Ni0 [21]. Therefore, Ni0 was produced under the isobutane treatment. However, the Ni2+ reduction could be related with isobutane and/or with hydrogen produced during the protolysis of isobutane as discussed in the next section. H2 and isobutane comparative treatments: analysis by TPR and in-situ dispersive X-ray absorption spectroscopy (DXAS) Fig. 4 , profile A, shows the H2-TPR profile of Ni/HZSM5 which indicates that the reduction under H2 starts above 350 °C. The first hydrogen consumption peak shows a maximum at 405 °C; further, at 500 °C, an additional consumption was observed. Under these conditions the total hydrogen consumption was 0.03 mmol H2/gcat; this amount corresponds about 10% of the theoretical H2 needed for the Ni2+ total reduction to Ni0. Therefore, one can assume that exchanged Ni2+ species in Ni/HZSM5 were only partially reduced to Ni0 by a H2 treatment up to 500 °C. After the H2-TPR experiment, the sample was analyzed by XRD, the corresponding pattern is shown in Fig. 1c; the presence of crystalline Ni0 is confirmed (JCPDS 03-065-0380). We have carried out an analogous TPR experiment with the Ni/HZSM5 catalyst under isobutane atmosphere. The corresponding TPR profile is also shown in Fig. 4, profile B. As can be seen, the isobutane consumption starts about 120 °C; there is a broad peak of consumption below 350 °C. These results indicate that the reduction in this case could start at much lower temperature than under H2. Additional isobutane consumption takes place further at 500 °C. In this case is not possible to do a quantitative analysis because the TCD signal could be masked by the products coming from the isobutane reaction. However, as stated above, Ni0 particles of about 10 nm were found by HRTEM analysis of the isobutane-treated Ni/HZSM5, indicating that the Ni2+ reduction took place during the treatment. XRD analysis of the Ni/HZSM5 catalyst after the thermal treatment under isobutane is also shown in Fig. 1b. It was not possible to unambiguously confirm by this technique the presence of a crystalline phase of Ni0 after the thermal treatment under isobutane up to 500 °C; this is probably related with the detection limit of this technique. From the TPR, XANES and HRTEM results shown here, it is reasonable to assume that under isobutane, a partial reduction of Ni2+ species occurred below 350 °C, resulting in the formation of small Ni0 particles after a treatment up to 500 °C. The reduction of Ni/HZSM5 catalyst with hydrogen and isobutane was also followed in situ during a thermal treatment from room temperature up to 500 °C by DXAS. Fig. 5 shows the evolution of DXAS profiles in three dimensions, intensity (I), temperature (°C) and energy (eV) for the treatment of Ni/HZSM5 with isobutane (Fig. 5A) and H2 (Fig. 5B). The initial spectra are consistent with the presence of Ni2+ bonded with oxide ions of the zeolite framework. In both cases, the treatment (with isobutane or H2) at increasing temperature produced a decrease in the intensity of the main peak at 8349 eV assigned to the presence of Ni2+ species; Ni0 did not exhibit such line [22]. However, the intensity (I) of the peak changed differently as a function of the temperature when Ni/HZSM5 was treated with isobutane or hydrogen as it is shown in Fig. 5A and 5B. The relative amount of reduced nickel was followed in situ by the variation of the I/I0 ratio (Fig. 6 ), where I0 and I are the initial intensity and the intensity at a given temperature of the line assigned to Ni2+, respectively. The decrease of I/I0 ratio occurred at a much lower temperature in isobutane than in hydrogen atmosphere (Fig. 6). The nickel reduction starts around 120 °C when isobutane is used as reducing agent, whilst it starts at about 350 °C when H2 is used. Moreover, the reduction under H2 appears to progress if temperature is increased up to 600 °C. These facts are in very good agreement with the results obtained from the TPR experiments. DRIFTS in-situ under isobutane atmosphere The evolution of hydroxyl groups of pristine HZSM5 (Fig. 7 ) and Ni/HZSM5 (Fig. 8 ) under isobutane atmosphere (20% v/v in He, 20 mL min−1) as a function of temperature was followed by DRIFTS. Spectra (a) in Figs. 7 and 8 correspond to the initial samples, HZSM5 and Ni/HZSM5 respectively, before feeding the alkane. The main bands located at 3735–3740 cm−1 and 3615–3620 cm−1 can be attributed to the υ(OH) stretching vibration mode of free silanol groups (SiOH) and bridging Si(OH)Al acidic sites, respectively; minor infrared absorptions between 3700 and 3650 cm−1 can be related to slight contributions of hydroxyl groups from EFAL species [23–26]. The relative intensity of the band at 3617 cm−1 with respect to that of 3740 cm−1 for the HZSM5 sample is higher than the corresponding for the exchanged Ni/HZSM5. This indicates a decrease in the amount of bridging Si(OH)Al groups for Ni/HZSM5 when compared with HZSM5 (spectra (a) in Figs. 7 and 8) and points to the exchange of Ni2+ with the more acidic hydroxyls groups in HZSM5 [27–29]. As stated above, Figs. 7 and 8 show the DRIFTS analysis for the isobutane interaction on HZSM5 and Ni/HZSM5 samples. The interaction of hydrocarbons with HZSM5 could result in vibrational perturbations of the OH group producing shift, intensity diminution or disappearance of the original υ(OH) bands present in the solid [30–32]. The interactions are expected to be stronger with the more acidic hydroxyl groups of Si(OH)Al type. The adsorption of isobutane on HZSM5 results in interactions with both internal and external hydroxyl groups [30]. Upon adsorption of isobutane on HZSM5 (spectrum b in Fig. 7), the intensity of the υ(OH) bands decreased. As expected, the intensity diminution was higher for the 3617 cm−1 band corresponding to Si(OH)Al groups. At increasing temperature under isobutane atmosphere and under He at 225 °C (spectra c–f in Fig. 7), a partial recovery of the intensity of both bands at 3740 cm−1 and 3617 cm−1, was observed. For Ni/HZSM5, after isobutane interaction the band at 3616 cm−1 practically vanished and the silanol band at 3737 cm−1 shifted to 3705 cm−1 (spectrum b in Fig. 8). At 225 °C under isobutane atmosphere the band due to silanol groups recovered its initial location at 3737 cm−1 (spectra d in Fig. 8). In contrast, the intensity of the band due to the Si(OH)Al acidic bridge groups was not restored meanwhile, a broad band in the 3600–3500 cm−1 developed (spectra d in Fig. 8); broad absorption features in this region can be associated with H-bonded hydroxyls [33]. However, when the hydrocarbon atmosphere was switched to helium at 225 °C (spectrum f in Fig. 8), the two bands initially present were again observed. Based on these results, one may propose that isobutane underwent two processes on the catalyst surface: protolysis by bridging acid (Si-(OH)-Al) sites producing an olefin (like isobutene) and hydrogen, and adsorption on silanol sites. On the other hand, the presence of nickel largely enhances dehydrogenation reactions [34], raising the amount of olefins [35], which in turn largely dominates the chemistry in the zeolite environment. Indeed, olefins are easily protonated by acid sites and strongly interact with acidic hydroxyls like bridge Si(OH)Al sites when compared with saturated hydrocarbons. The shift observed in the band corresponding to silanol groups could be related to a high intimate contact with hydrocarbon intermediate. The low temperature reduction of the Ni2+ species under isobutane could be related with a direct interaction between the isobutane and the exchanged Ni2+ cations which could be in the proximity of silanol groups. CO adsorption followed by in-situ DRIFTS for the characterization of reduced nickel species Characterization of nickel species in Ni/HZSM5 after H2 and isobutane thermal treatments was carried out by in-situ CO chemisorption followed by DRIFTS. In separate experiments, the Ni/HZSM5 catalyst was treated with isobutane/He (20% v/v) or H2/He (20% v/v) flow (20 mL min−1) at 225 °C in the DRIFTS cell for 30 min, then it was cooled down to room temperature with flowing He till only He was monitored by MS and finally the adsorption of CO (10% v/v in He; 20 mL min−1) was followed by in-situ DRIFTS. We chose 225 °C based on the TPR and DXAS results, at this temperature nickel species were not reduced under H2 but they were partially reduced under isobutane. The corresponding DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption after the isobutane and the H2 treatments are shown in Figs. 9 and 10 , respectively. In the former (Fig. 9), the progressive appearance with time on stream of well-defined bands with maxima at 2162 cm−1, 2130 cm−1 and 2091 cm−1 was observed. The band at the higher wavenumber exhibited a prominent shoulder centered at about 2195 cm−1; a component at 2114 cm−1 can be also observed. The broadness of the bands points to the participation of different species on the υ(CO) absorptions. The broad band above 2150 cm−1 corresponds to the υ(CO) vibration expected for CO coordinated on Ni2+ centers; the linear adsorption of CO on Ni2+ cations located in different positions could account for the different components [36–40]. However, a υ(CO) band at 2170–2169 cm−1 has also been related to CO bonded to zeolite acidic hydroxyls [39]. These bands are very easily removed under in-situ He flow at room temperature, see spectra f–i in Fig. 9. On the other hand, the coordination of CO to Ni+ species has been reported to give rise υ(CO) bands due to the formation of Ni(CO)x + carbonyl species [37–40]. A υ(CO) band at 2115–2109 cm−1 has been assigned to the Ni(CO)+ species [30,31]; υ(CO) bands at 2136 cm−1 and 2092 cm−1 to the υ s and υas modes, respectively, of Ni(CO)2 + geminal dicarbonyl [39,40]. Ni(CO)3 + species exhibits a set of bands at 2156 cm−1, 2124 cm−1 and 2109 cm−1 [39]. Thus, under our experimental conditions the coexistence of these species could be reasonably proposed. Moreover, under in situ He flow treatment at room temperature, the bands attributed to the Ni(CO)2 + species remains at least during 30 min (spectrum i in Fig. 9), only under an overnight He flushing they vanished (spectrum j in Fig. 9). The higher stability of the Ni+ carbonyls than those corresponding to the Ni2+-CO bonded species, is expected because a coordination with synergic sigma and pi backdonation bonding in the carbonyls of Ni+ exists. We have not detected relevant bands in the υ(CO) region 2080–2010 cm−1 which could be related to CO chemisorbed on Ni0 centers [36,38,41,42], yet the broad band centered at 2091 cm−1 could be contributed by the υ(CO) component due to linear CO on Ni atoms [30]. In fact, the equilibrium: Ni2+ + Ni0 ↔ 2 Ni+ has been proposed to exist under CO atmosphere [37,38,40]. [Ni(CO)x]+ species could be formed directly from CO adsorption on Ni+ or by the CO treatment of coexistent Ni0 and unreduced Ni2+; Ni+ and/or Ni0 would be formed during the isobutane treatment. Turning to the experiment carried out with the H2-reduced Ni/HZSM5 sample, the corresponding infrared results are shown in Fig. 10. As can be observed, in this case the adsorption of CO only give rise appreciable υ(CO) absorptions at the region attributed to the coordination of CO on Ni2+ sites (spectra b–d in Fig. 10) [36,40]. υ(CO) bands below 2160 cm−1, if exist, are of very low intensity. A main broad band with two relative maxima at 2167 cm−1 and 2197 cm−1 developed under CO flow. Moreover, these bands rapidly vanished after only 1 min under He flow (spectra e in Fig. 10) and they were recovered when CO was newly flowed (spectra f and g in Fig. 10). If reduced nickel species exist in this case, they are not available for CO coordination. These results confirm the presence of at least partially reduced Ni species, probably Ni+, after the isobutane treatment up to 225 °C but not after a H2 treatment in the same conditions. These results are in agreement with the TPR and in-situ DAXS results, Ni2+ exchanged in the Ni/HZSM5 is partially reduced after a treatment with isobutane at 225 °C, a progressive reduction process occurs above this temperature at least up to 500 °C. Insights in the bifunctional catalyst formation According to the obtained characterization data, nickel is mainly located as Ni2+ compensation cation in the HZSM5 frame. The reduction of Ni2+ exchanged in HZSM5 by isobutane could involve four steps: i) the hydrocarbon adsorption and migration to the Ni2+-zeolite site; ii) the hydride transfer from the alkane to Ni2+ site forming a Ni+-zeolite site and one Al(OH)Si acid site; iii) a second hydride transfer allowing reduction from Ni+ to Ni0; iv) by increasing the temperature, Ni0 formed small particles and the desorption of carbenion species restored the Si-(OH)-Al groups. Conclusions In this work we provide new insights into the formation of a bifunctional Ni/HZSM5 catalyst, with metallic and acid centers, under hydrocarbon atmosphere. Nickel, localized as compensation cation of the zeolite framework, was reduced by isobutane at lower temperatures with respect to its reduction in hydrogen as evidenced by DXAS-XANES and TPR results. The Ni(II) reduction under isobutane thermal treatment, is followed by an increase in the number of Brønsted acid sites determined by H/D isotopic exchange technique. The reduction pathway involves Ni2+ cations in ZSM-5 channels, which underwent sequential reduction to Ni0 through Ni+ species as concluded from DRIFTS results. Therefore, the balance between the number of metal and acid sites is expected to be in-situ modified by isobutane interaction resulting in a variation of the Ni/HZSM5 catalytic behavior. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional catalysts are widely applied to chemical and petrochemical industry. Herein nickel was introduced by ionic exchange in HZSM5 zeolite resulted in a Ni/HZSM5 catalyst that contains both H+ and Ni2+ as compensation cations of the zeolite framework. This catalyst has been characterized by using different in-situ techniques as Dispersive X-ray Absorption (DXAS), X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS), Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier-Transform (DRIFTS) spectroscopies, Temperature Programmed Reduction experiments (TPR) under both H2 and isobutane atmospheres, and by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) after exposure to H2 or isobutane. The reduction of Ni2+ species under isobutane started at about 120 °C, meanwhile under H2 stream the reduction started at 350 °C. Under isobutane, nickel undergoes a sequential reduction from Ni2+ to Ni+ and then to Ni0 and the number of Brønsted acid sites of the catalyst increased. By increasing the temperature (500 °C), sintering occurs and nickel particles are formed.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding bifunctional behavior of Ni/HZSM5 catalyst under isobutane atmosphere
